citations.narrative:
There was no written plan of veterinary care for dogs signed by the veterinarian available at time of inspection on April 5,
2023. The licensee was given more than 48 hours to provide documentation as required and requested but it was not
received.
A written program of veterinary care for dogs signed by the attending veterinarian is important because it documents that
the dog(s) are going to be provided adequate care, not limited to, but including an annual complete physical examination
from head to tail of each dog exhibited, annual vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs, parasite
testing and treatments, and other recommended care.
Each dealer, exhibitor, and research facility must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is
developed, documented in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities
must keep and maintain the written program and make it available for APHIS inspection.
Correct by May 1, 2023

There were no medical records or copies of medical records for "Rope" made available at time of inspection on April 5,
2023. The licensee was given more than 48 hours to provide copies as required and requested but they were not
received.
Medical records document that dogs are being medically cared for and are receiving all the preventive care and
treatments required by the animal welfare regulations.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available
for APHIS inspection. These records must include, but are not limited to, the identity of the animal and identifying marks,
dated examination findings including diagnosis, procedures performed, test results, the names of all vaccines and
treatments administered and dates of administration.
Correct by May 1, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
DAVID SABALA, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist n

narrative:
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There was no written plan of veterinary care for dogs signed by the veterinarian available at time of inspection on April 5, 
2023. The licensee was given more than 48 hours to provide documentation as required and requested but it was not 
received.  
 
A written program of veterinary care for dogs signed by the attending veterinarian is important because it documents that 
the dog(s) are going to be provided adequate care, not limited to, but including an annual complete physical examination 
from head to tail of each dog exhibited, annual vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs, parasite 
testing and treatments, and other recommended care. 
 
Each dealer, exhibitor, and research facility must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is 
developed, documented in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities 
must keep and maintain the written program and make it available for APHIS inspection. 
 
Correct by May 1, 2023

3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There were no medical records or copies of medical records for "Rope" made available at time of inspection on April 5, 
2023.  The licensee was given more than 48 hours to provide copies as required and requested but they were not 
received. 
  
Medical records document that dogs are being medically cared for and are receiving all the preventive care and 
treatments required by the animal welfare regulations. 
  
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available 
for APHIS inspection. These records must include, but are not limited to, the identity of the animal and identifying marks, 
dated examination findings including diagnosis, procedures performed, test results, the names of all vaccines and 
treatments administered and dates of administration.  
 
Correct by May 1, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
DAVID SABALA, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist n
